message_1: How many ways can you choose 3 items from a group of 7 distinct items if the order of selection does not matter?
message_2:
To find the number of ways to choose 3 items from a group of 7 distinct items without considering the order, we can use the combination formula:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of items (7 in this case) and k is the number of items to choose (3 in this case). The exclamation mark denotes the factorial of a number.

C(7, 3) = 7! / (3!(7-3)!)
= 7! / (3!4!)
= (7 × 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((3 × 2 × 1)(4 × 3 × 2 × 1))
= (7 × 6 × 5) / (3 × 2 × 1)
= 210 / 6
= 35

So, there are 35 ways to choose 3 items from a group of 7 distinct items if the order of selection does not matter.
